questions.text: Which of the following is the pathology in Cushing’s disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pituitary corticotroph adenoma The term Cushing’s disease refers specifically to Cushing’s syndrome caused by a pituitary corticotrope adenoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of Cushing’s syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Administration of exogenous glucocorticoids Overall, the medical use of glucocorticoids for immunosuppression, or the treatment of inflammatory disorders, is the most common cause of Cushing’s syndrome.

questions.text: Aldosterone is a mineralocorticoid steroid hormone that modulates activity directly and indirectly in the aldosterone-sensitive distal nephron which includes the late distal convoluted tubule, the connecting tubule, and the collecting duct system. Which of the following syndrome is due to excess aldosterone hormone?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Conn’s syndrome The most common cause of mineralocorticoid excess is primary aldosteronism, reflecting excess production of aldosterone by the adrenal zona glomerulosa. Bilateral micronodular hyperplasia is somewhat more common than unilateral adrenal adenomas.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A : Cushing’s syndrome is caused by excessive activation of glucocorticoid receptors. Option: B : In Addison’s disease, either glucocorticoid or mineralocorticoid deficiency may come first, but eventually all patients fail to secrete both classes of corticosteroid. Option: D : In Nelson’s syndrome , the loss of negative feedback from endogenous cortisol results in the growth of the pituitary tumour, often leading to an invasive pituitary macroadenoma (which causes local mass effects) and very high ACTH levels (which cause pigmentation).

questions.text: A 32-year female patient presents with low mood, swelling of limbs and amenorrhea for 2 months. Physical examination shows the following. What is the most probable cause of diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Excessive activation of glucocorticoid receptors
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Excessive activation of glucocorticoid receptors Central obesity, low mood, menstrual disorder, limb swelling along with the presence of purple stretch marks suggests Cushing’s syndrome . Excessive activation of glucocorticoid receptors is the cause. Amenorrhea (due to cortisol-mediated inhibition of gonadotropin release)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Conn’s syndrome. The clinical hallmark of mineralocorticoid excess is hypokalemic hypertension; serum sodium tends to be normal due to concurrent fluid retention, which in some cases can lead to peripheral edema. Option: C : In Addison’s disease, either glucocorticoid or mineralocorticoid deficiency may come first, but eventually all patients fail to secrete both classes of corticosteroid. Option: D: Progesterone is raised in pregnancy not estrogen and stria gravidarum is NOT purple .

questions.text: Which of the following is the investigation of choice for ACTH-dependent cortisol excess?
questions.correct_answer: D. Gadolinium enhanced MRI of Pituitary
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gadolinium enhanced MRI of Pituitary For ACTH-dependent cortisol excess, a magnetic resonance Image (MRI) of the pituitary is the investigation of choice, but it may not show an abnormality in up to 40% of cases because of small tumours below the sensitivity of detection. Characteristically, pituitary corticotroph adenomas fail to enhance following gadolinium administration on T1-weighted MRI Images.

questions.text: Which of the following oral agent with established efficacy in Cushing’s syndrome inhibits cortisol synthesis at the level of 11β-hydroxylase?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metyrapone Oral agents with established efficacy in Cushing’s syndrome are metyrapone and ketoconazole. Metyrapone inhibits cortisol synthesis at the level of 11β-hydroxylase .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A : The antimycotic drug ketoconazole inhibits the early steps of Steroidogenesis. Option: B : In severe cases of cortisol excess, etomidate, a n agent that potently blocks 11β-hydroxylase is administered by continuous IV infusions in low, non-anaesthetic doses. Option: D : Mitotane, a derivative of the insecticide o,p’DDD, is an adrenolytic agent that is also effective for reducing cortisol.

Extraedge:

In Cushing’s disease, the treatment of choice is the selective removal of the pituitary corticotrope tumour , usually via an endoscopic transsphenoidal approach. In some patients with very severe, overt Cushing’s (e.g., difficult-to-control hypokalemic hypertension or acute psychosis), it may be necessary to introduce medical therapy to rapidly control the cortisol excess during the period leading up to surgery. Similarly, patients with metastasized, glucocorticoid-producing carcinomas may require long-term anti-glucocorticoid drug treatment. In the case of ectopic ACTH syndrome, in which the tumour cannot be located, one must carefully weigh whether drug treatment or bilateral adrenalectomy is the most appropriate choice, with the latter facilitating immediate cure but requiring life-long corticosteroid replacement. In this instance, it is paramount to ensure regular imaging follow-up for the identification of the ectopic ACTH source.
